No steps to reproduce: it worked when I saved the file again.

I am almost 100% certain that the NPE didn't occur in EclipseFile.isModified 
(an inspection of the code reveals that the proper steps are taken to prevent 
any potential NPEs). The problem is that the stack trace provided seems to be 
currupt (or at least misleading). Notice the three occurances of 
EclipseFile.accept before the call to EclipseFile.isModified. This is not 
possible given the code involved. Do you have any idea what would have caused 
the traceback to appear this way?

I was able to determine that there were a few potential spots where NPEs could 
occur inside the methods invoked from EclipseFile.isModified. These will be 
fixed.

>Do you have any idea what would have caused the traceback to appear this way?
No idea: it happened after a normal save.

java version "1.3.1"
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.3.1)
Classic VM (build 1.3.1, J2RE 1.3.1 IBM Windows 32 build cn131-20020403 (JIT
enabled: jitc))

Since the stacktrace is confused by the VM or JIT, I have fixed the only spot I 
could find near EclipseFile.isModified() that could have caused an NPE. The fix 
was made in EclipseFile#getTimestamp() which was invoked from 
EclipseFile.isModified()
